In my math class we have learned a pretty neat schema for multiplying matrices, which is called "Falk's Schema". It has helped me a lot when doing matrix-matrix and matrix-vector multiplication.

The algoritm goes as follows: Draw a cross with enough space in the lower left and upper right quadrant to fill in your matrices. If you multiply the two matrices you have like this: M1 * M2, write the first matrix in the lower left and the second in the upper right quadrant. The quadrant in the lower right will then hold the product of M1 * M2.

For each cell, select the row in M1 and the colloumn in M2 that would get you to that cell (picture the product as a coordinate system, with the collumns of M2 being the x-coordinate and the rows of M1 being the y-coordinate), and start counting at 1. Multiply the n-th cell in whatever row you have selected in M1 with the n-th cell in whatever colloumn you have selected in M2. The increment your imaginary counter, and repeat the process. (n is whatever number you are counting at right now). Add all the products together, and that sum is what goes into the cell.

I like that schema because it gives a very nice visual way to see how you multiply any two matrices together, and it even shows you when you have messed up, namely when the number of collumns of M1 and the rows of M2 are not the same, because then the schema doesn't work (which is exactly when a product for the two matrices is not defined)

A(BC) means apply the overall effect of BC and then A. Of course, the overall effect of BC is equivalent to applying C then B based on what he explained earlier in the video.
